docs.lead_paragraph: For once, Congress and President Bush can agree: Medicare needs an outpatient prescription drug benefit. The federal program, begun in 1965, comes from an era when drug therapies were fewer and not as widely applied as they are today. This week Mr. Bush offered the most minimal way to follow through on his campaign promise of immediate relief for the elderly. His action makes Congress's task -- instituting a permanent benefit -- all the more urgent. Mr. Bush wants Americans who are enrolled in Medicare to join for-profit discount clubs that will negotiate with drug companies and pharmacies for low rates. Such clubs already exist, but Mr. Bush's plan would license perhaps five clubs. The newly renamed Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services would provide marketing assistance to the clubs in return for regulating their fees and practices.
docs.abstract: Editorial says weaknesses of prescription drug plan for Medicare recipients proposed by Pres Bush put onus on Congress to assemble plan that provides permanent, equitably determined benefit while controlling costs; says plan should have limited enrollment periods, reasonable co-insurance rates, cap on out-of-pocket costs, assistance for low-income elderly and competition among providers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever happened to the budget surplus? Just five weeks after President Bush signed into law the biggest tax cut in two decades, and six months after Congress and the White House raised their surplus projections again, Democrats were talking about deficits; Republicans were warning against tax increases; and the two parties were heading toward a 1980's-style showdown over guns versus butter as they considered next year's spending bills.
docs.abstract: Seeing Red, or Not**News analysis of re-emergence of bitter fiscal debates in wrenching shift from short-lived politics of prosperity; says change has as much to do with accounting and ideology as with any deterioration in fiscal outlook and hinges on differing definitions of budget surplus (M)
docs.snippet: Whatever happened to the budget surplus?    Just five weeks after President Bush signed into law the biggest tax cut in two decades, and six months after Congress and the White House raised their surplus projections again, Democrats were talking...

docs.lead_paragraph: In some circles, America's welfare reform has already been declared a success. Five years after Congress approved a time limit and work requirements for welfare, the number of people on the rolls has fallen by half, to six million, and many former recipients, including single mothers, have found at least part-time employment. But heartening as these facts are, it is premature to assume from them that the 1996 law has been a successful experiment. Five years is a short time for testing a substantively new social policy -- and these particular five years have not been ordinary ones. A significant question remains: To what extent are these positive outcomes related to the extraordinary economic boom in the late 90's and into 2000? We don't know yet whether the numbers will hold if the current slowdown continues or gets worse.

headline.main: The Real Test of Welfare Reform Still Lies Ahead

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by William Julius Wilson and Andrew J Cherlin on factors Congress must consider as it prepares to reauthorize--or modify--welfare reform law which will expire in 2002; says some are hailing reform as great success because of numbers of people who are now off welfare rolls; questions what extent positive outcomes are related to extraordinary economic boom since law was passed; says there is large group of women for whom transition to work has not been successful even with help of boom; says many had great difficulties balancing work and child care without health coverage or other elements of middle-class support system, like automobile, some savings and paid sick leave (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Affiliated Computer Services said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a unit of National Processing for $43 million. The unit processes health care claims, credit card applications and airline tickets. Affiliated Computer, a Dallas-based company that helps clients process and analyze documents, will get National Processing operations in Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Barbados and about 75 percent of the company's Mexican operations, the companies said. National Processing, based in Louisville, Ky., will take a fiscal second-quarter charge of $6 million from the sale. National Processing said it planned to focus on its business that settles electronic payments, like credit card transactions.

headline.main: AFFILIATED COMPUTER IS BUYING NATIONAL PROCESSING UNIT

docs.lead_paragraph: Five big health care companies promised today to work with President Bush to help Medicare beneficiaries obtain discounts on prescription drugs through a voluntary private program starting Jan. 1. But Democrats in Congress ridiculed the president's proposal as a trivial step to solve a huge problem. Under Mr. Bush's plan, the federal government will give its approval to drug discount cards issued by private companies that meet federal standards. The companies will pool the purchasing power of Medicare beneficiaries to negotiate discounts from pharmacies and drug manufacturers.

headline.main: Bush and Health Care Companies Promise Medicare Drug Discounts

docs.abstract: Five big health care companies pledge to work with Pres Bush to help Medicare beneficiaries obtain discounts on prescription drugs through voluntary private program starting Jan 1; Democrats in Congress call Bush's proposal trivial step to solve huge problem; under Bush's plan, federal government will give its approval to drug discount cards issued by private companies that meet federal standards; companies will pool purchasing power of Medicare beneficiaries to negotiate discounts from pharmacies and drug manufacturers; drug discount cards are big political gamble for Bush, because no one knows if they will work; if they do work, Bush will be able to claim credit for acting, especially if Congress is unable to adopt Medicare drug benefit before elections next year; Bush launches his new program at ceremony in Rose Garden; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Investors React Negatively To Argentine Austerity Plan Argentina, which has been struggling to contain an economic and banking crisis for several months, offered a new round of austerity measures that were not well received by investors and political leaders. Argentina's Merval stock index closed down 8.2 percent. It has fallen 24 percent in two weeks. Fallout has been felt the most in Brazil, Argentina's largest trading partner, and also in Mexico and Chile. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: One out of five poor children miss routine doctors' appointments because their parents cannot get them there, according to a national survey scheduled to be released today by the Children's Health Fund, a nonprofit agency based in New York that provides health care for children in low-income families. The survey, conducted among 903 families by Zogby International, a polling group, is an attempt to highlight barriers to delivering health care to the youngest Americans -- those who, compared with adults, need more regular medical attention. It is a problem even for children who are insured, the survey concludes.

headline.main: Transportation Hurdles Cited in Children's Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, said yesterday that it would close or sell numerous unprofitable H.M.O.'s and expand its business with self-insured companies and medium-size employers in an attempt to improve profitability. Aetna reported a $36.6 million operating loss for the first quarter of this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration said today that the weakening of the economy might push the federal budget surplus this year down to a level that, Democrats said, would portend a return to fiscal difficulties in the years ahead. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said the government would run a surplus this year big enough to meet the bipartisan commitment to use excess Social Security revenue only for reducing the national debt. And Mr. Daniels said there was no risk ''at present'' that the economic downturn would force the government to dip into Social Security surpluses in coming years.

headline.main: Declining Surplus Renews Debate Over the Budget Outlook

docs.abstract: Bush administration says weakening of economy might push federal budget surplus this year down to level that, Democrats say, would portend return to fiscal difficulties in years ahead; Mitchell E Daniels Jr, director of White House Office of Management and Budget, contends that surplus is in 'great shape,' but that economy is not in best of shape (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City and State have agreed to pay back the medical expenses and restore the health care coverage of thousands of poor city families who were wrongly cut from Medicaid when they were dropped from the welfare rolls. Officials will begin sending notices later this month to about 20,000 city families who were affected by a combination of faulty practices and computer coding errors that left many without coverage for needed medication and medical care, beginning in 1997. Their Medicaid coverage will be restored under the settlement, disclosed yesterday by lawyers who filed a federal class-action lawsuit on behalf of the families in 1998.

headline.main: Medicaid To Be Restored For Thousands
